The best curl creams can really take your hair care routine to the next level. For the uninitiated, these are styling products that are used on coily, curly, and wavy hair types in order to create more defined curls while also addressing issues like frizz and dryness. A good curl defining cream isn't always dependent on what your hair type or curl pattern is—sometimes the best things to look for are hydrating or nourishing ingredients that seal moisture into the hair. My hair, for example, is prone to dryness, and I've noticed that my curls respond a lot better to formulas that contain key ingredients like shea butter and coconut oil. The good news is that there are dozens of options to choose from, and we spent two months incorporating several different types into our regular hair care routines, before narrowing down our favorites to the list ahead. Whether you're looking for a multitasker that hydrates and prevents breakage (like our best overall winner!) or one that perfectly defines waves for your wash and go, there's something here for every hair type and need. The best curl defining creams, at a glance: Best Overall: Pattern Beauty Styling Cream Courtesy of brand Original photo from Paton Hardy testing Pattern Beauty Styling Cream ChevronChevron Pattern Beauty Styling Cream $28 Amazon Key ingredients: Shea butter, cacay oil, almond oil Size: 15 oz. Pros: Defines curls, prevents breakage Cons: Thick and may leave residue on the hair More often than not, curl creams are looked at simply as styling products that only help with defining curly hair, but that's only partly true, since some curl creams can also address frequent issues that people with curly, wavy, and coily hair face like damage and breakage. That's where the Pattern Beauty Styling Cream comes in—it's made with ingredients like shea butter, cacay oil, and almond oil to promote length and moisture retention and to prevent breakage at the ends. So not only will it give type 3 and 4 curls a crazy amount of definition, it puts in even more work to strengthen the hair from the inside out, something not all curl creams claim to do. “The texture for this one was really thick, but it gave my curls nice definition when I applied it,” says Condé Nast Content Licensing Associate, Paton Hardy, who has very fine, curly hair. “After the fact, it was a little drying for me, so I found it best to be used with a hair oil. It also smelled super fresh!” Best Drugstore: SheaMoisture Coconut and Hibiscus Curl Enhancing Smoothie Courtesy of brand Original photo from Danielle Jackson testing SheaMoisture Coconut and Hibiscus Curl Enhancing Smoothie Original photo from Danielle Jackson testing SheaMoisture Coconut and Hibiscus Curl Enhancing Smoothie ChevronChevron SheaMoisture Coconut and Hibiscus Curl Enhancing Smoothie $12 $8 (33% off) Amazon Key ingredients: Coconut oil, silk protein Size: 12 oz. Pros: Moisturizes really well, manages frizz, under $20 Cons: It's really thick, so your hair doesn't really absorb it This is an oldie but goodie that's a SheaMoisture bestseller (it was also highly-recommended by people in my immediate friend group when I first went natural in college), and it definitely lives up to the hype. It has ingredients like coconut oil and silk protein, which moisturizes the hair from inside the shaft, and it prevents common curl woes like frizziness. Sometimes I use this cream after washing and blowing out my coily, type 4 curls (I prefer to do twist outs on stretched hair), and even after applying it to my hair in a blown out state, the curls still manage to turn out looking like healthy spirals. I'm also a really big fan of the way this product makes my hair feel—after unraveling my twists, I usually find myself continuously touching my curls because of how satisfied I am with how soft and moisturized my hair feels. My only gripe is that this is a product that sort of sits on your hair—it's pretty thick, so that's to be expected—so if you're someone who touches your hair often, you'll definitely be able to feel that there's something on your strands, though it doesn't leave behind an oily or greasy film. Best for Moisturizing: Briogeo Curl Charisma Leave-In Conditioner Courtesy of brand Original photo from Danielle Jackson testing Briogeo Curl Charisma Leave-In Conditioner Original photo from Danielle Jackson testing Briogeo Curl Charisma Leave-In Conditioner ChevronChevron Briogeo Curl Charisma Leave-In Conditioner $24 Sephora...

The beauty industry has evolved into one of the most dynamic and profitable sectors in the global economy. Fueled by innovation, celebrity endorsements, social media influence, and shifting consumer preferences toward skincare, sustainability, and inclusivity, cosmetics brands have grown into global powerhouses. While thousands of brands exist, only a few dominate the global market in terms of brand value, reach, and consumer loyalty. Here are the top 10 most valuable cosmetics brands in the world in 2025, based on market presence, revenue, brand equity, and global influence. 1. L'Oréal (France) Estimated Brand Value: $12.5 Billion L'Oréal remains the undisputed leader in the global cosmetics industry. With a presence in over 150 countries and a vast portfolio of sub-brands (including Lancôme, Maybelline, Kiehl's, and Garnier), L'Oréal offers products for every skin type, budget, and beauty need. Their innovation in skincare, haircare, and makeup is unmatched, and the company continues to invest heavily in research and development. Their forward-thinking digital campaigns and sustainability initiatives — such as refillable packaging and green chemistry — have also strengthened their reputation among younger, eco-conscious consumers. 2. Estée Lauder (USA) Estimated Brand Value: $10.3 Billion Estée Lauder Companies owns a prestigious range of beauty brands, including MAC, Clinique, Bobbi Brown, La Mer, and Tom Ford Beauty. Known for luxurious skincare and elegant branding, Estée Lauder has secured a loyal base of affluent consumers worldwide. What sets them apart is their strength in high-end skincare and fragrances, and their aggressive push into emerging markets like China and India. Their digital transformation, especially during the pandemic, positioned them as a strong e-commerce player in the luxury beauty space. 3. NIVEA (Germany) Estimated Brand Value: $7.5 Billion Owned by Beiersdorf, NIVEA is a heritage brand with global recognition and trust. Known primarily for its skincare and body care products, NIVEA is especially dominant in Europe, Asia, and Latin America. While not a luxury brand, NIVEA's consistent quality and affordability give it massive global appeal. The brand has recently focused on developing sensitive skin-friendly formulations and expanding into men's grooming, increasing its reach across demographics. 4. Chanel (France) Estimated Brand Value: $6.8 Billion Chanel is the epitome of timeless luxury. Though more famous for fashion and fragrance, Chanel's cosmetics division — including foundations, lipsticks, and skincare — is among the most coveted in the world. The Chanel №5 perfume remains one of the best-selling fragrances globally. What elevates Chanel's value is exclusivity. Its limited product drops, premium pricing, and elegant in-store experiences ensure it remains aspirational and rarefied. 5. Dove (UK/USA) Estimated Brand Value: $6.2 Billion A Unilever brand, Dove is widely recognized for its inclusive, real-beauty approach. Famous for body washes, deodorants, and moisturizing products, Dove markets itself on self-esteem, confidence, and body positivity. Its messaging resonates strongly with Gen Z and millennials who favor authenticity over airbrushed perfection. Dove's initiatives such as the “Real Beauty Campaign” and sustainability goals contribute significantly to its brand equity. 6. Clinique (USA) Estimated Brand Value: $5.7 Billion A subsidiary of Estée Lauder, Clinique is one of the pioneers of dermatologist-developed skincare. It's known for its “3-Step Skin Care System” and hypoallergenic, fragrance-free products. Clinique has successfully positioned itself at the intersection of clinical credibility and beauty, which appeals to consumers who are ingredient-conscious and result-driven. Its expansion into clean beauty and focus on men's skincare has kept it relevant in a fast-changing market. 7. Shiseido (Japan) Estimated Brand Value: $5.3 Billion...

Seit einer Weile teste ich den Maybelline Lifter Glaze Lip Oil Balm in der Farbe Berry Haze. Erst hatte mich das Produkt irgendwie nicht so angesprochen, aber der niedrige Preis von rund 5 Euro und der kleine aber feine Hype auf Social Media haben dafür gesorgt, dass ich das Produkt dann doch mal mitgenommen habe. Ich war neulich erst erstaunt, dass ein ähnliches Produkt von Manhattan so viel teurer war, daher finde ich 5 Euro für Maybelline echt nicht zu teuer. Das Design vom Produkt ist schlicht, gefällt mir aber schon gut. Vielleicht hätte man das Packaging noch an die Farbe des Produkts anpassen können, aber wollen wir mal keine Wunder erwarten. Das Produkt verspricht Pflege und Farbe in einem und “zart getönte Lippen”. Nun habe ich eine relativ dunkle Farbe genommen, finde aber, dass es für mich eher zur Kategorie dekorative Kosmetik als zur Kategorie Lippenpflege gehört. Oftmals sind solche Lippenpflegestifte, die auch Farbe haben, eher störend und schmierig, das ist hier nicht der Fall. Trotzdem finde ich "zart getönte Lippen" trifft es irgendwie gut. Ich finde, dass man bei meiner Farbe einen sehr hübschen mavig/rosanen my lips but better Look bekommt, aber auch keinen super spiegelden Glosseffekt, nicht wie zum Beispiel bei Fenty Beauty. Dafür merkt man das Produkt aber auch kaum auf den Lippen, das ist sehr angenehm. Ich merke, dass ich immer wieder zum Lifter Glaze greife und zu "Marktforschungszwecken" (😜) habe ich jetzt auch noch eine zweite Farbe gekauft. Ich bin mal gespannt, wie meine Meinung dort ausfallen wird, denn die Farbe ist deutlich heller. All in all bin ich ein bisschen leidenschaftslos. Das Produkt gefällt mir gut. Ich greife immer wieder dazu, auch wenn ich nun wirklich auch andere Produkte da hätte. Die Farbe gefällt mir sehr gut und passt zu den meisten Makeups. Für den Preis kann man sich das auf jeden Fall mal anschauen, ist aber für mich jetzt kein weltbewegendes must-have Produkt. Kennt ihr die Lifter Glaze Lip Balms von Maybelline? Gefallen sie euch? Welche Farben habt ihr gekauft? #maybellinelifterglaze #maybelline #neuinderdrogerie #neubeidm #neubeirossmann #beautyblogger_de #lippenstiftliebe

I am 12 years old and almost a teenager. i see beauty gurus on youtube talk about charlotte tilbury and fenty lip products, what i also see on youtube are 10 year olds at sephora, and comedic parodies about how insufferable they are(i am aware that some products are harmful to children's skin barriers, and beauty standards/social media are producing a generation of insecure women). im getting pretty interested in beauty and self care and i want to get something for myself- maybe some highlighter. but im scared of being like one of those ten-years olds, technically i am in the same phase in my life as them and only 2 years older. i have always considered myself to be some what of a tomboy, and have been taught to demonize femininity. so i also have some underlying hesitation on what to get for myself. and i understand that im in a period of my life where i feel like the ugliest person alive. so if i get something, do i fall into the category of sephora kids? also-any beauty tips for sensitive skin?
